Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trademarks Opposition Board (TMOB) decision
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence presented on GIA's reputation and distinctiveness in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; GHI trademark registration refused
Burden_of_Proof: Respondent failed to prove absence of likelihood of confusion
Legal_Rule: Confusion assessed based on inherent distinctiveness, length of use, nature of wares/services, degree of resemblance, and surrounding circumstances
Standard_of_Review: De novo review by Federal Court
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court's authority to consider new evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: GHI trademark likely to cause confusion with GIA in the context of gemology services
Review_Standard: Correctness or de novo as applicable to questions of law and mixed fact-law
Key_Evidence_Considered: Reputation and acquired distinctiveness of GIA in Canada
Similarity of three-letter acronyms in same industry
Applicant_Challenge: Registration of GHI opposed by GIA
Defendant_Response: Failed to rebut likelihood of confusion
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of registration due to potential consumer confusion
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition followed by Federal Court appeal
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Application for registration of GHI mark
Governing_Rule: Section 6 of the Trade-marks Act regarding confusion
